name: Letter from Woverius Hamburgensis, Johannes, to Clusius, Carolus, 1591-11-22

Diplomatic.text: Salve, Claris[sime] Clusi. Ut ego animum tuum in deliciis habeo! Virtus caussae est et beneficentia; utraque tu equidem ita polles, ut me prorsus in admirationem, immo ruborem des. Narravit rem actam Tabell[arius] quam parate tu litteras meas Lipsio tradendas susceperis absque ullis omnimodo rugis, nedum stomacho. At mihi ignoto talis, taceo de notis. In os tibi dicam, Vir Claris[sime], ad haec stupeo. [[Vide]] Ceterum vide humanitas quam potenter possiet: ignobilem te diligere, sive ut propritim deamare occoepi. Sed quid laudes oggero? Oggero, sed corditus. Rogamus te magnopere, curabis nuperrimas litteras Lipsio tradi; cautio erit necubi delitescant, quia bona in eis auri pars delitescit. At cui rei, inquis. Non mihi, Vir claris[sime], non mihi, sed magno Lipsio quem tu amas, scio. Utut est, hoc beneficii te non in sterili segete obesse intellegas, si quando ad te aut ad Lipsium. Avere te iubeo, Vir Claris[sime], humanitatis tuae aetatem memor. Hamburgi, pridie Id[us] Novemb[res]. T[uus] Ianus a Wouweren. [Address:] Viro Claris[simo] Carolo Clusio. Francofurt [Clusii manu:] 1591. Jani a Wouweren. Hamburgi, pridie Id[us] Novembr[es] vet[ere stilo]. Accepi Francofurti XI Kal[endas] Decembr[es] vet[ere] [stilo]. Respondi postridie.

annotations.text: Lipsio: Lipsius and Woverius had met during the former's short stay in Hamburg. Woverius had written to him via Frankfurt (the letter is not preserved); Lipsius answered on 14 June 1591 (ILE 91 06 14 W). The letter Woverius is alluding to must be his answer to Lipsius, which is not preserved either.

annotations.text: propritim: Very rare: 'properly', cf. Lucr. 2, 975. Lipsius had warned Woverius not to exaggerate in his use of archaic or unusual vocabulary.

metadata.value: The letter was dated following the Julian calendar
